posts.cooked:
Summary

Signal Desktop for macOS is displaying numerous contacts from an unknown third-party’s address book, in addition to my actual contacts. Many people, from many countries where I’ve never been and where I don’t know anyone. Most of them don’t have a Signal account, some do.

Environment

  • Platform: macOS v.26.0.1
  • App: Signal Desktop v. 7.73.0
  • Affected: Desktop app only (iOS app unaffected)
  • Launch Method: Custom .command file with system proxy configuration
  • Proxy: Cloudflare Zero Trust (Proxy mode)

Steps to Reproduce

  1. Launch Signal Desktop via custom .command file (proxy-enabled)
  2. Attempt to create a new chat
  3. Access Contacts list

Expected Behavior

Contacts list should display only my legitimate contacts.

Actual Behavior

Contacts list contains numerous unknown entries that belong to a completely different person’s address book. These contacts are not present in:

  • macOS Contacts system app
  • iPhone Signal app (displays correct contacts only)
  • Other messaging apps (e.g., WhatsApp)

Launch Script

To avoid censorship, the app is launched via the following .command file:

#!/bin/bash

# Extract current SOCKS proxy host and port from system settings
SOCKS_HOST=$(scutil --proxy | awk '/SOCKSProxy/ {print $3}')
SOCKS_PORT=$(scutil --proxy | awk '/SOCKSPort/ {print $3}')

if [[ -n "$SOCKS_HOST" && -n "$SOCKS_PORT" ]]; then
    export HTTPS_PROXY="socks5://$SOCKS_HOST:$SOCKS_PORT"
fi

open -a Signal
Screenshots:

Screenshot 21824×1444 134 KB

Screenshot 11824×1444 144 KB

link_counts.title: I am recieving texts and calls that aren't from the sender

posts.cooked: I’d file a bug report on GitHub if I were you. And don’t forget to include debug logs .

I reported the bug through the website’s form, but I received no response. Therefore, I’ve duplicated the bug here.
The debug log is attached for your reference.
I hope this helps.
I’m not a developer. You can create an issue here: GitHub · Where software is built

of course, do not give any sensitive information, if profiles belong to actual people !

does these profiles belong to ordinary people or scammers?

is there picture and or first name? basically profile? not just username or phone number.

i did get some little spam or scam messages from some unknown individuals to desktop client in linux system. my guess is that they used ACI to send message.

actual messages are send using ACI (or UUID), phone numbers or usernames are used to get certain ACI.

long shot theory, is there some kind of mess up with ACI identifiers !

I agree it’s possible these where spam users contacting you. Signal does a poor job of cleaning old profile / group data. Most reliable way to get rid of this is to delete all apps, reinstall and register again WITHOUT providing the Signal PIN.

This is not spam.
This is not a chat list. My chat list contains only my chats. There are contact list entries, and most of them don’t even have a Signal account.
I have no idea who these people are.
Those are likely going to be numbers that you have in your phone’s address book, either manually added or automatically picked up by your phone.
I don’t have any of them listed in my iPhone address book or in iOS Signal contacts either, and I don’t use Signal on any other devices.

That’s weird, but still seems likely they’re coming from your phone in some way – possibly contacts that Signal knows about and still has in its internal database even though they’re not in your address book. The mobile apps no longer show contacts for numbers that aren’t Signal accounts, so they wouldn’t show up there, but maybe the desktop app still shows those. I haven’t experimented with that behavior.

All I know is, the only place the Desktop app gets contacts from is the mobile device it’s linked to.

Exactly. That’s why I think Signal staff should investigate it.

Herohtar:

maybe the desktop app still shows those

These inclusions appeared a couple of days ago, as part of one of the app updates. They had never been present before.

After a while, I decided to reinstall the Mac app. However, wiping the macOS app completely and reinstalling it caused all the “aliens” contacts to reappear in the app’s contact list. Initially, the app only displayed my real contacts, and I thought the problem was resolved. But after some time, the other contacts reappeared again.

To investigate further, I installed the Signal app on another, fresh Windows PC. Upon launching the app for the second time, I discovered that all these ghost contacts were still present in my Contacts list. This suggests that the aliens are stored somewhere in my Signal profile, but they remain invisible in the iOS app.

ouinner:

This suggests that the aliens are stored somewhere in my Signal profile, but they remain invisible in the iOS app.

That’s the explanation indeed, it happened to me as well. Old contacts and people I had interacted with appeared in search on desktop but not on mobile.

My contact list includes a small number of my actual contacts, but it also contains a significant number of unknown names and phone numbers that are readily available without any search. These contacts are certainly not my old acquaintances or people with whom I have previously communicated.

Do you happen to be (or have been) member of Signal groups these alien members are/were member of as well? Because that way, they (knowingly or not) shared their profile with you. Signal is not supposed to display non-existing chats with these, but that might be the actual bug.

It appears that this is indeed the case. Whenever I join a new group, stay for a while, and then leave, this list is filled with a significant number of new, unfamiliar contacts.

Unlike the previous contacts, all these new ones have a Signal profile.

So, the previous contact group persists from the group I watched a few months ago. Most of these contacts don’t have a Signal profile because they likely didn’t use the app for a while, and their profiles were deleted.

Yes, this is a serious bug.
